site_title: ASEAN infrastructure gap turns negatives into positives
content:
ASEAN infrastructure gap turns negatives into positives

A worker labors at the Nam Tha 1 hydroelectric dam construction site, being built by Power Construction Corp. of China Ltd. (PowerChina) and to be operated by Chine Southern Power Grid Co., in Bokeo Province, Laos, July 29, 2017. PHOTO:BLOOMBERG

HSBC INSIGHTS--If a spending deficit of US$1.2 trillion in six key Asian economies and a rising tide of protectionist rhetoric in Europe don’t seem the most promising combination of business prospects, think again.

Add in China’s ambitious Belt and Road Initiative, and together they make a compelling case of the potential for a multi-year boom in investment and construction that will create entirely new economic ecosystems.

Belt and Road at its most basic is a strategy to build the transport links and logistics capacity to boost the flow of trade between China and more than 65 countries in Asia, the Middle East, Africa and Europe to an estimated US$2.5 trillion annually in the coming decade, from about US$1 trillion now.

Meanwhile rapidly-ging numbers of increasingly affluent urbanites in the economies of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) are fuelling demand for housing, schools, hospitals, roads, railways, airports and other facilities.

Meeting that demand in ASEAN’s six biggest economies – Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam – means investment of an estimated US$2.1 trillion out to 2030, according to analysis by HSBC.

That same analysis shows governments currently have plans in place to deliver just US$910 billion of it.

Given the right incentives, the private sector can bridge that gap – especially if companies in Asia and Europe can find the right opportunities to work together.

Business connections between ASEAN and Europe are already strong.

Companies from the European Union contribute about a sixth of total foreign direct investment into economies in the 10-nation bloc, according to ASEAN data. The US$20.1 billion worth of EU commitments in 2015 were more than twice those from China.

Europe’s commitment to the gth opportunity in ASEAN in the face of economic uncertainties at home has seen annual trade flows increase to $201 billion in 2015 from $US147 billion in 2010.

Now a new accelerant for economic activity is emerging to drive prosperity for ASEAN’s 625 million inhabitants that could see them g their consumer spending power to twice that of the UK by 2025.

Nation-building infrastructure investment is providing the fuel.

Infrastructure has been a bug bear in Southeast Asia for decades where hard infrastructure such as roads, railways and ports, and soft infrastructure such as water and sewerage plants, schools and hospitals are in profound need of repair, expansion or development.

With the increasing urbanisation of populations around ASEAN, infrastructure has become an unmistakable priority for countries across the bloc.

And this is where China’s Belt and Road Initiative has added a new dimension to the business possibilities.

More than 300 Chinese-funded enterprises had set up in 26 economic cooperation zones in eight ASEAN countries, investing a total of US$1.77billion, by October 2016 under the auspices of Belt and Road projects.

ASEAN economies including Malaysia, Thailand and Indonesia have already launched Belt and Road-related deals with China, with several projects now entering implementation stage and many more in the pipeline.

The planned high-speed rail line running from southern China through Laos to Thailand’s industrial east coast, and a port in Vietnam are prime examples.

European engineering, construction, maintenance, logistics, architecture and business services firms – still battling economic headwinds at home – could and should be firmly in the mix to pick up the opportunities of the anticipated Asian infrastructure boom.

German companies, well-known for their tunnel drilling machinery, components and maintenance already supply projects in Singapore. Elsewhere, Dutch companies are dredging for land reclamation activity linked to port projects.

These projects are not one-offs, built in isolation. The connected nature and the underlying intent of Belt and Road means that they must be part of a broader, self-sustaining commercial ecosystem.

Getting those economic ecosystems to function at their full potential will need companies able to reach across national borders and with the vision to see the value of building connections between regions to stimulate business activity that does not yet exist.

Research from the economic think tank, Bruegel, concludes that European nations will be big Belt and Road winners from improvements to transport infrastructure and reductions in freight costs.

Bruegel’s analysis finds that all 10 of the top trade beneficiaries would likely be European - Belgium, the Netherlands, Slovakia, Austria, Hungary, Denmark, Moldova, Germany, Bosnia/Herzegovina and Poland – with an annual trade boost of at least 8.2 percent each.

When tied with the development needs of ASEAN, this could be the biggest opportunity to stimulate international trade since the creation of the World Trade Organization, more than 20 years ago.

Perceiving the broader economic opportunities presented by the Belt and Road Initiative will be a crucial differentiator in the decades ahead.

Stuart Tait is Group General Manager and Regional Head of Commercial Banking, Asia Pacific

site_title: 下来几天料不会出现烟霾
content:
下来几天料不会出现烟霾

速读狮城

我国接下来几天受跨境烟霾影响的可能性不高。

国家环境局昨天发文告说，截至昨晚6时，我国24小时内的空气污染指数介于24点至51点，处于良好至中等水平。一小时PM2.5指数则介于每立方米4微克至12微克，处于正常水平。

环境局说，未来24小时的空气污染指数料维持在良好水平至中等水平低端，一小时PM2.5指数则维持在正常水平。

我国和印度尼西亚苏门答腊多处昨天不同时分出现降雨。由于云层遮盖，昨天在苏门答腊观察到的热点只有一个。

环境局预测，我国今天将吹南西南风，上午较迟时分和下午较早时分多个地区将下雷阵雨。

苏门答腊下来几天预计也将出现降雨。

环境局说，公众可以继续正常活动，但若感到身体不适，特别是年长者、孩童或患有肺部和心脏慢性疾病者应马上求医。

site_title: NATAS参展旅行社： 国人对四川旅游兴趣锐减
content:
NATAS参展旅行社： 国人对四川旅游兴趣锐减

受到九寨沟地震影响，报名参加四川旅行团的国人急剧减少，旅行社估计，这方面的需求须要再过一段时间才会恢复正常。

本地最大规模的旅游盛会全国旅行社协会（NATAS）旅游展过去三天在新达新加坡会展中心举行，共有超过80家展商参加。

受访旅行社指出，九寨沟是国人前往中国旅游的热门景点之一，但该区在本月8日发生地震后，让不少原本想要前往四川旅游的国人望而却步。

华宫旅游市场与通讯总监佘柳华透露，尽管公司仍在旅游展上提供四川旅游配套，但参展期间却无人问津。

调整四川行配套  改往蜀南竹海等未受影响地区

她说：“毕竟地震上周才刚发生，肯定会直接影响到需求。公司目前正在探讨为四川旅游配套进行调整，如果九寨沟景区仍关闭，我们就会前往没有受到影响的地区，例如南部的蜀南竹海。”

康泰旅行社市场部高级经理曹惠美则指出，仍有一些国人报名参加四川旅行团，收到的相关订单比平时“稍微减少”。

她说：“公司目前正向已经购买四川旅游配套的顾客进行接洽，提供延迟出发或更改目的地的选择。我们也在参展期间接到一些订单，这表示还是有国人愿意去四川，但旅行团可能会避开九寨沟，到四川其他地方。”

大通旅游市场部经理卓琼华则说，公众对于四川旅行团的询问度减少，不过她相信再过几周就会恢复正常。

昨天前往旅行展的周锦雄（60岁，科技经理）原本考虑到四川或云南旅游，因地震决定避开中国，最后选择了日本冲绳。

他说：“去四川的话就一定要看九寨沟的著名景色，现在景区受到严重损坏，再加上各种安全问题，我们可能会在一两年后才考虑到四川旅行。”

NATAS指出，这次旅游展反应非常热烈，首两日吸引超过4万8000名访客，比去年同期增加超过五成。

content:
国庆群众大会20日举行 可上早报数码看直播

李显龙总理星期天将发表国庆群众大会演讲。公众当晚可通过zaobao.sg网站观看直播。《联合早报》也将与民情联系组于下个星期六联办华语对话会，收集国人对国庆群众大会的反馈。

总理公署发文告说，李总理星期天（20日）傍晚6时45分会先以马来语和华语演讲，休息约45分钟后，再于晚上8时15分发表英语演讲。

国庆群众大会连续第五年在宏茂桥工艺教育学院（前称工艺教育中区学院）举行。这也是李总理自2004年上任以来，发表的第14场国庆群众大会演讲。

公众可上zaobao.sg网站、总理公署的YouTube频道、李总理的面簿专页或民情联系组（REACH）面簿专页观看演讲直播；本地电视台和电台也将广播演讲内容。总理公署YouTube频道直播的华语和马来语演讲会为听障者提供手语通译。

李总理的面簿和推特账号也将提供即时报道。国人在发面簿贴文和推特时，可使用#ndrsg的标签（hashtag）。

民情联系组将在国庆群众大会后举行数场活动收集国人的反馈。其中，与早报联办的对话会将于8月26日（星期六）下午3时至5时，在国家图书馆戏剧中心举行。

对话会由总理公署部长陈振声和总理公署、外交部兼人力部政务部长陈振泉担任主讲嘉宾。陈振泉也是民情联系组主席。早报采访组副主任何惜薇负责主持对话会。

site_title: 达规模效应 可发展休闲设施 业者可考虑联合竞标
content:
达规模效应 可发展休闲设施 业者可考虑联合竞标

许宝琨近来探访本地多家农场，了解业者的经营情况，也率领本地业者到中国和日本等国家进行考察。（取自许宝琨面簿）

农场业者将获准拨出部分土地用于农耕以外的用途，所以如果业者合作、协调开发，国人喜爱的“农家乐”不一定会就此消失。

本轮的农业土地招标，其中一个重点在于推高农产量。许宝琨指出，新加坡土地有限，提供农业用地的核心目标必须是保障粮食安全，但与此同时，政府会允许业者拨出最多10％的土地，用于其他用途。

许宝琨说：“以一块两公顷的农业用地为例，10％的土地有2万平方英尺，相等于大约20间四房式组屋。这块地并不小，你可以放个巴士站、访客中心甚至是个小商店售卖农产品，吸引人们到农场参观你种植和养殖的过程。”

我国农场目前大多是零散个体户，各做各的，合作程度不大。许宝琨指出，目前已有一些小型菜园将蔬菜交给大型菜园，采用后者的品牌和包装出售，接下来业者应探讨如何更紧密合作。

许宝琨提议业者考虑采取新商业模式，集合资源提呈联合竞标书，一次过争取数块相邻的农业用地。如此一来，业者就可共享资源，取得一定的规模效应，这对新加坡而言是双赢局面。

许宝琨说：“我们不反对三人联合竞标几块地皮。有了较大一片相连的土地，他们就能共享包装机和器械等，甚至是共用员工。”农场也可以将用于非粮食生产的土地结合起来，兴建较大型的休闲娱乐设施，如设立餐厅，售卖以本地农产品制作的佳肴等。

据许宝琨透露，政府将在招标中做出灵活安排，接受联合竞标书。但业者是否合作，那是商业考量，政府无法介入。许宝琨说：“我们可以做媒，但要不要结婚还得他们自己决定。”

我们不反对三人联合竞标几块地皮。有了较大一片相连的土地，他们就能共享包装机和器械等，甚至是共用员工。——许宝琨

site_title: Belt and Road to Bring Mutual Economic Benefits for Southeast Asia and China
content:
Belt and Road to Bring Mutual Economic Benefits for Southeast Asia and China

Leaders shake hands during  the 19th ASEAN-China Summit  in Vientiane on September 7, 2016.FILE PHOTO: LIANHE ZAOBAO

HSBC INSIGHTS--In the wake of more isolationist political thinking in the West, with many developed economies turning inward, China is reaching out, seeking stronger trade and investment links with its economic partners.

China's Belt and Road initiative (BRI) is a prime example of this reaching out policy. Under the initiative, China aims to trigger demand for materials and goods at home by investing in strategic infrastructure projects abroad, ging economic ties along its old Silk Road to Europe and along newer maritime links in and around Asia and as far away as Africa, covering all potential points in-between.

At its heart, the plan is to enhance global supply chains primarily though debt-financed infrastructure projects, across more than 60 countries. China expects annual trade with these countries to be worth US$ 2.5 trillion within a decade1 – up from US$ 1 trillion in 2015.2

Given the economic importance of Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) to China, and its geographical proximity, a key focus of Belt and Road initiative is its burgeoning economies. Formed in August 1967 the ASEAN region is one of the most developed economic zones in the Asia region and the world.

2016 marked the 25th anniversary of the open-dialogue relationship between China and ASEAN. Economic relations between China and ASEAN economies have been ging strongly. By the end of May 2016, the two-way investment had exceeded US$ 160 billion, with ASEAN remaining a major destination for Chinese companies.3 Bilateral trade has also increased 60 times from US$ 7.96 billion in 1991 to US$ 472.16 billion in 2015. ASEAN and China are seeking to double their trade value, setting a target of US$ 1 trillion by the end of 2020.4

Belt and Road initiative will play a key role in this, further bringing together two of the world's most dynamic economic regions by strengthening economic linkages amongst the ten members of ASEAN, as well as between ASEAN member countries and China.

If major Western economies really are going to roll-back on their traditional global economic links, China's Belt and Road policy is set to fill some of the openings that are set to develop.

For ASEAN member countries, the initiative will help address an infrastructure deficit, and lift industrial development. While the formation of the ASEAN Economic Community (AEC) a year ago is bringing Southeast Asian economies together as a single market and production base, the Belt and Road initiative will offer further integration by developing physical infrastructure and a robust trade regime. The region will be ideally positioned to sit at the centre of global value chains.

For China, the Belt and Road initiative will provide an ideal platform to develop ties with neighbouring Asian countries while fostering the development of its own extensive high-speed rail network as a means to export high-end technology and services. With more than 20,000 kilometres of track laid, China has more high-speed rail than the rest of the world combined.5

The effort has already made some practical achievements. Among the countries of ASEAN, Malaysia, Thailand, Laos and Indonesia have joint Belt and Road deals with China, mainly in railway construction.

There will be a new high-speed rail line running from southern China through Laos to Thailand's industrial eastern coast. China has given a new pledge to cash-starved Laos for the construction of a US$6 billion railway project linking Laos' capital Vientiane to China's southern Yunnan province by 2020. Once operational, the railway will the Laos' longest and fastest, with an average speed of 160 kilometers per hour and 60 percent of the line being bridges and tunnels.6

Meanwhile, the 7,000 kilometre Singapore-Kunming Rail Link is already taking shape. Beijing has also won the contract to build Indonesia's first national high-speed rail link – a US$5.1 billion, 150 kilometre rail project connecting the capital Jakarta to Bandung, Indonesia's third-largest city.7

Infrastructure financing until now has been a challenge for most of ASEAN countries. With the exception of Singapore – which has a highly developed infrastructure base – and to a lesser extent Malaysia, the nations of Southeast Asia are by and large confronting major infrastructure financing deficits.

Indonesia for example, the largest economy in Southeast Asia, now spends just two to three per cent of its GDP on infrastructure. However, the need for better roads and railways for long-distance distribution and improved urban transport is quite evident.

Fortunately for China's Belt and Road initiative goals, seed funding for infrastructure projects along the Belt and Road has mainly come from the Chinese government with support from the Chinese commercial banks.

China has also set up three new financial institutions to help fund the Belt and Road infrastructure goals: the Asian Infrastructure Investment Banks (AIIB), the New Development Banks and the Silk Road Fund. Between them these three institutions have a registered capital of US$ 240 billion, and they are starting to become active investors along the Belt and Road routes.

In addition, more than 300 Chinese funded enterprises have been set up in 26 economic cooperation zones in eight ASEAN countries, investing a total of US$1.77 billion by October 2016.8

Even these combined funding capabilities cannot fully meet Asia's immense need for infrastructure financing. The Asian Development Bank estimates that US$750 billion a year will need to be invested in Asia between now and 2020 as developing nations strive to raise their economic productivity and deal with rising urbanisation.9

However, Beijing's drive and financial commitments are sizeable, and will have a significant impact across Southeast Asia. Belt and Road is an historic initiative of colossal scale and ambition, setting out a vision for China's investment in the coming years.

Implementing the Belt and Road agenda will require a high level of mutual cooperation, understanding and trust. But with careful analysis and handling of the regulatory, political and financial risks involved, it will provide Southeast Asia and China quality and long-lasting economic gth – especially in these times of global uncertainty.

site_title: 不知因故障被令暂关闭 赴圣淘沙瞭望塔持预购票游客扑空
content:
不知因故障被令暂关闭 赴圣淘沙瞭望塔持预购票游客扑空

前天出现故障的圣淘沙旋转瞭望塔已被令暂停运作，使不少预购景点门票的游客失望而归。（何家俊摄）

瞭望塔业者受询时并未透露有多少预购门票的访客受影响，但据记者现场观察，短短一小时内就有约10组持票的游客到柜台询问详情。已购票的游客可在圣淘沙任何一个售票处退款，或免费兑换成其他指定景点的入门票，未使用的票同样可获退款。

出现故障的圣淘沙旋转瞭望塔被令暂停运作，不少预购门票的游客不知情，前往圣淘沙时扑了个空。

位于圣淘沙英比奥山顶区的圣淘沙旋转瞭望塔前天下午5时35分左右突然故障，导致观景舱内的38名访客和一名操作员受困半空中四个多小时。瞭望塔约50层楼高，观景舱最终在晚上约9时45分安全降至地面，没有人在事故中受伤。

建设局昨天回复《联合早报》询问时指出，已下令圣淘沙旋转瞭望塔业者暂停运作，也派出工程师到现场调查事发原因。但该局并未进一步透露调查进展，以及何时解除封闭令。

记者昨午走访圣淘沙旋转瞭望塔时，瞭望塔的两个柜台前张贴着“景点关闭直至另行通知”的告示牌。不过，仍有不少已经向旅行社预购瞭望塔入门票的游客不知道发生故障，兴致勃勃地前往瞭望塔。

瞭望塔业者Sky Tower私人有限公司主管美最时（Alexander Melchers）受询时并未透露有多少预购门票的访客受影响。但据记者现场观察，短短一小时内就有约10组持票的游客到柜台询问详情。

美最时指出，在本月12日或之前购买瞭望塔全额门票的访客可在圣淘沙任何一个售票处退款。由于门票有效期为三个月，公众也可选择等到瞭望塔开放后再使用门票。

至于通过旅行社预购的门票和向圣淘沙购买的景点套票，则可免费兑换成其他指定景点的入门票；未使用的票同样可获退款。

来自印度的游客库马尔（32岁，商人）前天抵达新加坡后，便通过旅行社购买两张圣淘沙景点套票。

业者：公司无法解决故障才向民防部队求援

他受访时说：“我和太太原本很期待可以在瞭望塔上欣赏圣淘沙的全景，没想到居然发生故障。我们过两天就要回国了，看来也没有机会再上瞭望塔。虽然可以换取其他景点的入门票，但瞭望塔已经是我们在圣淘沙的最后一站，我们只好亏了这两张门票的钱。”

中国游客苏桐（21岁，学生）则预购了四张圣淘沙景点套票。他说：“抵达瞭望塔后扑了个空，我和家人不免感到失望。但还好我们能换到别的景点，所以对行程没有太大影响。

尽管瞭望塔是在前天下午5时许出现故障，但业者直到晚上7时10分才通知民防部队寻求支援。

对此，美最时解释：“根据公司制定的紧急事故应对计划，只有当公司人员无法通过手动操作解决故障时，才会向民防部队求援。”

他强调，Sky Tower、民防部队，以及圣淘沙发展局向来都有定期展开演习，观景舱内也备有应急的食物、水、和厕所，以备不时之需。

site_title: 张志贤出席柔佛公主婚礼
content:
张志贤出席柔佛公主婚礼

副总理兼国家安全统筹部长张志贤伉俪今天前往马来西亚柔佛，出席柔佛公主阿米娜的婚礼。

外交部文告说，张志贤伉俪是以李显龙总理特别代表的身份出访，出席王室婚礼和婚宴。

阿米娜是柔佛苏丹依布拉欣与苏丹后拉惹查丽苏菲雅唯一的女儿，在六个孩子中排行第二。她将嫁给出生于荷兰的丹尼斯（Dennis Muhammad Bin Abdullah）。丹尼斯曾担任柔佛JDT足球队概念店和咖啡厅经理，后来成为新加坡淡滨尼流浪球会行销经理。

外交部说，张志贤出席这场盛典，反映新加坡和柔佛两地的密切和友好关系。

site_title: 下榻酒店严重毁损 九寨沟旅游团20人分三批安全回国
content:
下榻酒店严重毁损 九寨沟旅游团20人分三批安全回国

到九寨沟旅行遇上地震回国的吴清顺（右）与李碧霞昨早抵达樟宜机场，李碧霞见到前来接机的曾兄弟旅行社代表，上前与她拥抱。（邝启聪摄）

七级地震发生时正在九寨沟旅游的这20名新加坡游客，在曾兄弟旅行社安排下，经平武县前往成都后，昨天都已安全回国。旅行社也会协助受影响游客向保险公司索赔。

受九寨沟地震影响，一度滞留当地的20名随曾兄弟旅行社旅游团出国的新加坡游客，昨天已安全回国。

中国四川九寨沟上周二（8日）晚上9时19分发生七级地震时，到访这个著名景点的曾兄弟旅行社20人旅游团正下榻受灾严重的九寨天堂洲际大饭店。旅行社事后安排团员离开九寨沟，先到四川平武县，再前往成都。

他们前天和昨天已分别乘搭胜安航空（SilkAir）MI935及MI937的三趟班机，从成都安全回返本地。

昨天清晨4时43分回国的团员吴清顺（62岁，烧焊工）讲起当时的情景还心有余悸。地震发生时，他和太太李碧霞（56岁，家庭主妇）正与其他团员在酒店餐厅用餐。强烈摇晃导致大小不一的铁条从餐厅天花板掉落，还砸中李碧霞的双腿，造成瘀青。

临危不乱细心照顾  游客大赞酒店员工

吴清顺说：“餐馆天花板的灯饰在一声巨响后坠落，周围一片漆黑，我急忙躲到餐桌下面。餐馆照明恢复后，我便赶紧和太太及另一名团员逃离酒店。”

地震发生后，该酒店部分结构和墙壁坍塌，因此团员都被安排到附近停车场度过一夜，隔天才启程离开九寨沟。

带着太太和子女回国的曾锦安（53岁，自雇人士）虽然心情仍未平复，但酒店服务员在发生灾难时临危不乱，对住客照顾有加，令他印象深刻。

他说：“我们在停车场露天睡了一晚，酒店员工冒着危险回酒店拿毛巾给我们，让我们在寒冷的夜里能够保暖。这点做得很好，他们对游客真的很照顾。”

曾兄弟两天来都派代表到樟宜机场接机，并送上燕窝，安慰受影响游客。该旅行社告诉《联合早报》，旅行社已尽力并顺利地让所有顾客安全回国，并会协助受影响游客向各别保险公司索赔。

另一16人旅游团  行程继续后天回国

除了曾兄弟，华宫旅游也有一支旅游团行程受九寨沟地震影响而中断。该旅行社的16名游客将在四川西南部继续观光行程，旅游团预计后天（16日）回国。

site_title: China firms' going global gives Singapore a major hub role
content:
China firms' going global gives Singapore a major hub role

Singapore is expected to remain the preferred location for regional treasury centres of both Chinese and international institutions directly participating in the Belt and Road strategy in Southeast Asia.FILE PHOTO:LIANHE ZAOBAO

HSBC INSIGHTS--2016 was the year that Chinese companies truly went global. Collectively, they announced over US$225 billion of acquisitions abroad more than double the total announced in 2015.

While a large part of Chinese foreign direct investment whether acquisitions or other types of investment will be infrastructure-focused, that will not be the only sector that benefits.

In recent years, China's focus has shifted from buying what the country needs to what it wants; it has gone from basic resources to assets such as brands and technology that cater to the demands of an affluent consumer society.

This is all part of the evolution of China's overseas direct investment (ODI). Investment in the Belt and Road region is showing a similar trend. In 2015, the five countries Singapore, Russia, Indonesia, the UAE and Turkey collectively accounted for about 90 per cent of China's total ODI in the Belt and Road region, with Singapore alone taking up more than half (representing an amount equivalent to at least US$6.4 billion), and investment going into financial services, manufacturing, wholesale and retail services.

At the same time, the profile of those doing the buying has changed; Chinese private-sector companies are now overtaking state-owned enterprises (SOEs) as the major outbound investors. China's Ministry of Commerce says that non-SOE enterprises accounted for 65 per cent of total ODI for the first nine months of last year.

Case in point: In 2016, the Alibaba Group paid a whopping US$1 billion for a controlling stake in online retailer Lazada Group, so as to tap into the region's lucrative consumer market.

Lazada followed suit in November with the acquisition of Singapore-based online grocer, Redmart.

A major driver of China's going-out strategy is to internationalise its currency, the renminbi. Singapore, as one of the largest recipients of China's investments and the third largest offshore clearing centre, has a big role to play in this. Increased regional capital expenditure spend is expected to have a significant element of renminbi investment, resulting in its increased use as a trade, transaction and cash-management currency.

In addition, Singapore is expected to remain the preferred location for regional treasury centres of both Chinese and international institutions directly participating in the Belt and Road strategy in Southeast Asia, resulting in increased capital and project finance through the Republic.

Singapore's position as a renminbi hub has been validated through the extension of the currency's cross-border lending scheme through the Chongqing Connectivity Initiative, the renewing and enhancing of its bilateral currency swap arrangement, and the doubling of the Renminbi Qualified Foreign Institutional Investor scheme quota to 100 billion renminbi (S$29.2 billion).

Singapore corporates have demonstrated foresight as early adopters of the currency. While the renminbi's volatility may have triggered concerns in the near term, its susceptibility to market forces is actually indicative of its journey towards becoming a mature global currency. In fact, the recent HSBC RMB Internationalisation Study showed that renminbi usage by corporates in Singapore has almost doubled in a year from 15 per cent in 2015 to 26 per cent.

The internationalisation of the renminbi has come a long way the finish line is almost within sight but more confidence measures need to be taken before it establishes itself as a full-fledged reserve currency.

That said, Singapore's connectivity with the currency is a two-way street and usage will be bolstered by Singapore's investment into China as well.

SZHKSC introduces foreign investors to not only the world's fifth largest marketplace (at over US$3 trillion in market capitalisation), but also to a diversified selection of small, private companies that are the mainstay of China's "new economy" and which account for over half the companies listed on the exchange.

Finally, the recent inclusions of Chinese onshore bonds in fixed-income emerging market and regional government bond indices by significant industry players are promising, and may pave the way for the eventual inclusion of Chinese stocks and bonds in global indices.

These are certainly developments to watch out for in the future their impact for investors everywhere, including those in Singapore, would be significant.

As China continues to balance between reform, development and stability, it may have to increase its focus on certain types of capital flows for the benefit of the broader economy in the short term.

However, the country's significant progress in financial reforms, capital account opening and the internationalising of the renminbi shows Beijing's commitment in this direction.

In the long run, this bodes well for Singapore and the Asean region. As one of the largest recipients of China's investment and a major financial hub, Singapore is definitely a key enabler and beneficiary with a major role to play.

The author is Senior Vice President, RMB internationalisation, HSBC Singapore

This article first published in The Business Times, 31March 2017
